customer_name: C JS GREAT CATS WORLD PARK INC
site_name: CJ'S GREAT CATS WORLD PARK, INC.

citations.narrative:
On the southeast area of the park there are empty metal cages and stacks of cage panels piled against the perimeter
fence. These stacks of cages and panels stair-step up to approximately 6 feet in height and extend 30 feet along the
fence. Because of proximity to the perimeter fence these stacks provide a platform that reduces the effective height of the
perimeter fence to approximately 2 feet. Animal well-being is compromised whereby an animal potentially escaping its
enclosure could use this structure to facilitate escape from the park or lead to injury or death to the animal, other animals,
or the public. The perimeter fence must be maintained so that it inhibits animals from going over the fence as well as
functioning as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. Correct by removing objects and structures
away from the perimeter fence to prevent animals from using them as a means of escaping over the perimeter fence.
Correct by 25MAY2025.

In the area directly adjacent to the food storage and food preparation building there are piles of refuse including but not
limited to broken or used wood pallets, scrap and stacked animal crates buried behind other debris inhibiting inspection in
those areas and permitting hiding places for rodents to reside. The lack of housekeeping and sanitation attracts pests into
the facility, resulting in unpleasant odors, and may contribute to the spread of disease. Accumulations of debris can
provide areas which can harbor disease-transmitting pests and could increase health risks to the animals. Correct by
ensuring that premises (buildings and grounds) are kept clean, in good repair and accumulations of trash are placed in
designated areas and cleared as necessary in order to protect the animals from injury, protect their health, and to facilitate
prescribed husbandry practices.

During the inspection, dead and dying flying insects and excessive amounts of rodent feces were found in food storage
and processing areas. Rodent feces and flies were found including but not limited to the following areas:
• Around two pallets of loosely covered red meat in the storage freezer.
• Next to totes of exposed meat, on food prep tables, and on the floor of the meat prep room.
• On top of the chest-freezers which are housed under an open shelter outdoors.
Lack of an adequate pest control program can negatively impact the health and well-being of the animals as it can foster
the contamination of feed and transmission of diseases. Correct by developing and maintaining a safe and effective
program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests. Correct by 25MAY2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
On the southeast area of the park there are empty metal cages and stacks of cage panels piled against the perimeter 
fence. These stacks of cages and panels stair-step up to approximately 6 feet in height and extend 30 feet along the 
fence. Because of proximity to the perimeter fence these stacks provide a platform that reduces the effective height of the 
perimeter fence to approximately 2 feet. Animal well-being is compromised whereby an animal potentially escaping its 
enclosure could use this structure to facilitate escape from the park or lead to injury or death to the animal, other animals, 
or the public. The perimeter fence must be maintained so that it inhibits animals from going over the fence as well as 
functioning as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. Correct by removing objects and structures 
away from the perimeter fence to prevent animals from using them as a means of escaping over the perimeter fence. 
Correct by 25MAY2025. 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
In the area directly adjacent to the food storage and food preparation building there are piles of refuse including but not 
limited to broken or used wood pallets, scrap and stacked animal crates buried behind other debris inhibiting inspection in 
those areas and permitting hiding places for rodents to reside. The lack of housekeeping and sanitation attracts pests into 
the facility, resulting in unpleasant odors, and may contribute to the spread of disease. Accumulations of debris can 
provide areas which can harbor disease-transmitting pests and could increase health risks to the animals. Correct by 
ensuring that premises (buildings and grounds) are kept clean, in good repair and accumulations of trash are placed in 
designated areas and cleared as necessary in order to protect the animals from injury, protect their health, and to facilitate 
prescribed husbandry practices. 
3.131(d) 
   
Sanitation. 
During the inspection, dead and dying flying insects and excessive amounts of rodent feces were found in food storage 
and processing areas. Rodent feces and flies were found including but not limited to the following areas:  
•  Around two pallets of loosely covered red meat in the storage freezer.  
• Next to totes of exposed meat, on food prep tables, and on the floor of the meat prep room.

•  On top of the chest-freezers which are housed under an open shelter outdoors.  
Lack of an adequate pest control program can negatively impact the health and well-being of the animals as it can foster 
the contamination of feed and transmission of diseases. Correct by developing and maintaining a safe and effective 
program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests. Correct by 25MAY2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
